"For such a trend-setting
university, it is unusual that Johns
Hopkins does not have a studentrun radio station," said Brian
Liddicoat, a member of an ad hoc
radio committee. Although
Hopkins still holds the license for
the all-student station WJHU,
WJHU became a professionally
run radio station in October 1986.
Student involvement in the
radio station now consists of
select internships in the different
departments of the station. The
initial aim of the committee,
therefore, is "to get students on
the air," explained Liddicoat.
After meeting with the
manager of the University of
Connecticut radio station on
November 18, the committee has
looked at alternatives to an allstudent-run radio station until
Hopkins can obtain an on-air
frequency.
The committee is exploring the
possibility of establishing a cable
radio station through United
Cable of Baltimore. By encouraging students to acquire cable,
Hopkins would have a means of
funding the operation and of increasing their listening audience.
The committee is also considering a carrier station transmitting
on the wiring in Wolman,
McCoy, the Charles, and the
Blackstone, as well as the
Homewood campus. As Liddicoat said, such a system would
reach a "reasonably good percentage of the school population."
Time-sharing on another frequency which is owned by a
Baltimore area high school has
also been suggested.
Because these alternative stations would not be subject to
Federal Communications Commission (FCC) regulations, the
radio station would not have to
adhere to advertising restrictions
on educational stations.

Council reviews semester
by Priscilla O'Briant
As a prelude to Wednesday's
Student Council meeting, Council President Lou Giangailio said
that he hoped this meeting would
he "a summation of the Student
Council activities of the
semester." "I'd like to try and
prioritize for next semester," he
said.
The meeting dealt with all of
the issues that had been raised this
semester, including the student
radio station and the ESL
(English as a Second Language)
classes for teaching assistants.
The meeting began at 8:00 with
a short presentation concerning
"Teach for America." A new
program in the U.S. organized to
help mitigate teacher shortages,
it recruits seniors to be teachers.
They are then sent to a training
session, which is fully paid for by
the sponsors of the program, and
placed in a teaching position, for
which they receive the same pay
as a fully accredited teacher. Participation in the training session
requires a two-year commitment
to teaching. There will be an information session on Monday at
6:00 in Conference Room A of
Levering Hall.
For this meeting, committee

reports were suspended, yet each
committee chair gave a brief summation of progress, long-term,
and short-term goals. Mark
Friedman and Ravi Veeraswamy
were chosen as chairs of next
year's MSE Symposium. The
topic will be "Dreams Deferred:
Perspectives on Race Relations."
The upcoming spring elections
were briefly discussed. The council hopes to get a voting booth
along with a banner in addition
to the traditional posters, in order
to encourage voter turnout.
The junior class reported that
its sale of poinsettias and
Christmas trees is progressing
well and that seats on the shuttle to Owings Mills Town Center
are almost sold out. Also, Tuesday at midnight, the junior class
will be holding a holiday study'
break in the Garrett Room of the
library. The freshman class announced that it is organizing a
dorm-decorating contest, and is
trying to develop an "adopt a
family" program in which each
dorm would adopt a family for
the holiday season.
E.S.L. classes were noted to
have been very successful in
teaching foreign teaching
assistants the culture of the
classroom as well as the

language.
The Student Council Representatives to the Book Center Committee have initiated concrete
steps to improve Book Centek
services on the campus. Their
agenda includes making all
lockers outside the bookstore
functioning and available by
December 16, and providing
complete guidelines to faculty in
providing booklists to the Book
Center, to avoid costly delays.
The Book Center will allow Student Council members to examine requisitions to help them
compile booklists for the Student
Council hook-swap.
Two students from the Student
council will attend the A.A.U.S.
(American Association of
University Students) National
Conference to be held in
Washington, D.C. from February
28 through March 4.
A new van driver for the
school's escort van service has
been hired part-time, and more
drivers are being sought.
Guidelines for responsible shuttle use are going to be handed out
to students.
The Entertainment Committee,
proposed by juniors Howie Fried
and Charles Stewart, was also
discussed at the meeting. It was

noted that, without funding from
the president's office, the committeecould take as long as five
years before being implemented.
They are, however, looking into
corporate sponsorship.
The Student Activities Fee was
put on the long-term agenda,
although some council members
commented that a larger budget
is necessary for many of the activites ai.d projects in which
students wish to participate. Also
under discussion was early fall
registration, which would have
students registering before Labor
Day. As a result, final exams
would be pushed up from
December 23, and approximately a week would be added to the
mid-year break.
A proposal for a speaker series
to take place during the second
semester was brought before the
council. The series would take
advantage of the expertise of
Hopkins' faculty in addressing
issues such as the environment or
present-day events in Eastern
Europe and be sponsored by both
the Student Council and the
News-Letter. The format would
be a little more personal than in
the MSE Symposia.

Non-discriminatory discrimination
Recently, it was brought to the attention of the NewsLetter that applications for job opportunities at Hopkins
contain the following statement: "The Johns Hopkins
University is an equal opportunity employer and does not
discriminate on the basis of race, color, sex, religion, age,
homosexuality, national or ethnic origin..."
We received a private communication from an applicant,
who pointed out that "...clearly naming homosexuals as
a group against which the university does not discriminate
is, in itself discriminatory. It seems that this label would
be more "at home" in a statement like, 'The University
does not discriminate against Blacks, Women, Jews,

Homosexuals, or Mexicans.' Such a statement is on the
surface non-discriminatory, but is clearly offensive,
discriminatory, and oppressive."
This may at first glance seem a relatively minor point,
but it is an important distinction. The term that applications and all University documents should use is "sexual
orientation," rather than specifying homosexuality. It is
vital that the misleading term contained within the University's statement of non-discrimination be corrected immediately, especially if the University is sincere in its expressed desire to attract a diverse staff, faculty, and student body.

The will is not the deed (but it may be a committee)
As the semester draws to a close, it's time for one and
all to take a moment to reflect upon exactly what Student
Council accomplished during the past four months. Council
finally decided upon dates for Spring Fair after lengthy
debates and attempts to relocate the MCATS. Discussions
with security helped result in the installation of lights in
the Lower Quad.
A survey conducted by the Communication Committee,
which attempted to assess student concerns about the Book
Center, showed that over 80 percent of those polled supported the idea of a book swap. There is no question that
an alternative to the buy-back policy held by Barnes and
Noble has been needed for some time, and the proposed
Student Council Books-swap is an excellent solution. To
quote Margaret Thatcher, however, the will is not the deed.
One rather exciting potential change, as the result of
Council efforts, could be some improvements in the Book
Center services at Homewood. As with anything connected
with Barnes and Noble and Seiler's, the most rational thing
to do is adopt a we'll-believe-it-when-we-see-it attitude.
Yet when the buying rush begins next semester students
will enjoy increased security measures such as functional
lockers (a truly revolutionary concept) and bag-checkers.
So it seems the Student Council Representatives to the
Book Center Committee have managed to initiate sane
.improvements in the way Barnes and Noble serves the
University. The News-Letter hopes that Council and its
many committees will continue their work towards

cultivating a positive atmosphere here at the happy
Homewood homefront.

Time for a new station
For the first time in several years, a credible proposal
for the return of a student run radio station has been put
forward. The transformation, in 1985, of the previously
student-run WJHU into a professional radio station was
a regretable decision on the administration's part in the
first place. Although the decision to take WJHU out of
student hands was apparently influenced by administrative
concern about a perceived lack of adequate student cornmittment to the station, this should not be held against current efforts at radio revival.
University support for the proposed radio station would
be an acknowledgement of extensive undergraduate efforts
to overcome a reputation for apathy, and a very positive
indicator that undergraduate needs and interests have
become a genuine administrative concern.
This year's attempt to revive student radio at Hopkins
appears to be particularly well-conceived and sincerely intended. Whichever of the multiple suggestions for broadcast mediums are chosen, whether on FM or through the
University's electrical system, we strongly recommend
concrete steps towards the speedy renewal of student-run
radio at Hopkins.

Craig Freeman

In a lecture that was more
Cosby than canon, Henry L.
Gates disappointed during his lecture 'Race and the Canon.'
Gates is not your average lecturer. After all, this is the man
who criticizes the canon for returning values to the 'antebellum
esthetic position when men were
men and men were white, ... and
when women and people of color were voiceless, faceless servants and laborers, pouring tea
and filling brandy sniffers in the
boardrooms of old boys' clubs.'
As one of the editors of the Norton Anthology of Afro-American
Literature, Gates certainly came
well versed in the disenfranchisement of minorities in literature.
I expected Gates to come
prepared to battle the last bastion
of Eurocentric philosophy in
Baltimore. He must have been
briefed on the history departments' History of Africa, where
the only reference to blacks came
during a half hour lecture on
slavery. The truly sad part is the
History of Africa is one of only
four non-Western courses offered
on the undergraduate level by the
history department.
As a student and now professor
of African-American studies,
Gates could also have criticized
the school for not having one

faculty member knowledgeable
about black literature or history.
As it stands now, any student at
Hopkins desiring any more than
a passing comment on blacks in
literature or history must go to
Morgan State University.
Instead of addressing the issues
of race, education, and/or the
canon, Gates reminisced for an
hour on his childhood in the
presegregation South. At an institution that seems open to
change, Mr. Gates' words could
have helped enumerate the concerns of many students at
Hopkins. Instead he chose not to
help alter the views he struggled
so hard to overcome.

In the past couple of weeks I
have noticed a change brewing at
Hopkins. I think it started with a
successful Cultural Festival,
where people got to sample international cuisine and observe the
cultural kaleidoscope that
Hopkins has to offer.
The seed planted by Cultural
Fest grew quickly: the showing
of Spike Lee's movie "Do The
Right Thing" attracted far more
than anyone expected. It was
even more astonishing to see so
many stay for the discussion
afterwards.

"Do The Right Thing" need
only be the beginning. There is
a plethora of culturally diverse
events in the upcoming months to
expand everyone's horizons, but
they all depend on Universitywide support.
Take, for example, Black
History Month. The Black Student's Union is working with
several other groups to make this
February unforgettable. Umoja
Sasa, an African storytelling
group will open the month. The
African Heritage Dinner gives the
community a chance to taste
native African culinary treats, and
features an African dance troupe
for entertainment. The Grammy
award-winning gospel group
Take 6 will also perform in late
February.
These events were not scheduled only for black students. Ninety
percent of the black students have
tasted African cuisine, seen
African dancers, or even sung
gospel. The events were planned
to improve cultural awareness on
a previously lacking campus.

Soundgarden—Louder Than Love (A&M)
While most of the free world seems to be
celebrating or analyzing the end of the 1980s, the
Hopkins Barnstormers seem hopelessly mired in
a trilogy that hurls us backward into the 1970s.
First was David Mamet's "Sexual Perversity in
Chicago," then Neil Simon's "California Suite."
Now comes Ralph Pape's "Say Goodnight,
Gracie."
Pape's work is a meandering rant on the meaning of life; besides the dated language, "Say
Goodnight, Gracie" is as refreshing or stale as
it ever was. The themes are cliched and universal, but the play works because it uses specificity
and anecdote to its advantage.
The setting is Greenwich Village: the living
room of struggling roommates Jerry (Robert Bell)
and Ginny (Pamela Becker). Jerry has just received his umpteenth rejection for an acting job, and
even the slightest transgression is enough to set
him off.
He isn't huffing and puffing alone for long,
however. Old friend Steve (Josh Mcllvain) arrives, gorilla mask draped over his head, for a protracted argument with Jerry over turkey noodle
soup. "What are you doing," Jerry asks, "rehearsing a monologue?" Exasperated by Steve's correct assessment of his histrionics, Jerry accuses
Steve of having a bad case of drug-induced
"silliness."
Soon Ginny arrives home; an airhead on a mission from God. She spends her opening moments
on stage cleaning up the apartment, offering empty
generalities to Jerry and Steve like an impatient
kindergarten teacher. She's not listening—she's
straightening. Becker really chews up the role, all
hands and hair, especially later in the play when
she puts on her bell-bottom jeans. The vintage
costume seems to invigorate her.
Steve, Jerry, and Ginny are planning to attend
their high school reunion that night, along with

There's much to be said for Seattle's Soundgarden, first that many people have been waiting
for years to see what would happen when this
potential Next Big Thing got a shot at major-label
glory. "Louder Than Love," the band's entry into
the big leagues, offers plenty of interesting
possibilities. Soundgarden's celebration/parody of
raw phallic power and bare-chested maleness is
without doubt more engaging (and direct) than the
rituals of teenage petting and drunkenness supervised by the competition.
Although that alone is refreshing, it proves no
less contrived or silly after the initial fascination
wears off. Soundgarden undresses the rock cliche,
lies it down, revels in it, and leaves it apparently
despoiled and discredited. In fact, though, the band
usually just leaves it lying, which accounts for
much of the record's appeal.
Musically, "Louder Than Love" is a rocket
ride, a nail-biting trip that alternates graceful,
smooth coasting with a turbulent, disturbing grinding. But Soundgarden, appropriately, is more
likely to make hips swing than to elicit raised-fist
salutes. The band's sound pays off most handsomely when it shocks or surprises—although your
cup is sure to overflow once or twice in the course
of this 50-minute romp, several of the cuts bust
out too late or from too little.
The bottom line (for those who need one):
"Louder Than Love" is far more provocative than
most of the boom-boom floating around and glutting the pipes these days. It doesn't smother all
of its lumps in makeup; instead, it paves right over
them. At the same time, "Louder Than Love"
is totally ridiculous and pretentious, and I wish
Soundgarden would put its collective tongue back
in its own cheek.
—Terry Swords

As it applies to rock and roll music, the term

debut for Columbia, collected from two previously
released EPs on the diminutive Texas Hotel label,

Leader/songwriter Frank Orall and the additional six Poi Dogs play mostly acoustic instruments, and quite a lot of them: flugelhorns,
cellos, Latvian lap harps, accordions, banjos,
violins, and a battery of wood blocks and percussion all go into forming the Poi Dog sound.

avoids sounding ordinary. This has something to

Bonham—The Disregard of Timekeeping
(Columbia)
Not surprisingly, references to Led Zeppelin
dominate "The Disregard of Timekeeping."
Drummer Jason Bonham is, after all, the son of
late Zeppelin drummer John Bonham, and most
of the songs here practically trip over themselves
to accomodate young Jason's Zeppelinian style.
And wait a minute. . . who's that singer? He
sounds exactly like Zeppelin vocalist Robert
Plant—what a coincidence! This record is what
I imagine one of those "tribute" bands would turn
out if they ever played their own material.
Bonham clearly wants to tap into Led Zeppelin's
glory (and who wouldn't),but the group has none
of their idols' wit or inspiration from which to
draw power, nor the legend with which to justify
self-indulgence. Extending a never-give-up-youcan-make-it anthem (predictably called
"Dream")to nearly eight minutes doesn't make
it "Kashmir," or even "Stairway to Heaven."
The swishy keyboards, however, do make it sound
like Foreigner, and that's worse than the lamest
Led Zeppelin rip-off.
—Terry Swords
Billy Joel—Storm Front (Columbia)
Okay, I realize that it's not too hip to be a Billy
Joel fan; realize, too, that his last few records have
been a little, well, thin in spots But that said,
Joel's twelfth and newest release isn't too bad.
We're not talking about some recently unearthed
Beatles master tape here, of course: "Storm
Front" isn't a great record, and doesn't hold up
that well even next to Joel's best work.
Still, Joel has toughened up his sound for
"Storm Front,' endowing the record with an
Eighties-style synthetic tone—it's about time—
and shoving the drums and percussion to the front
of the mix. The album kicks off with the peppy
"That's Not Her Style," a commentary on the '
tabloid exploitation of an unnamed celebrity (undoubtedly his wife, model Christie Brinkley). The
next song, "We Didn't Start The Fire," is
guaranteed to elicit a reaction from every listener.
Against a lilting synthesizer background, Joel
rhythmically recites names, events, novels,
movies, etc. from the past 34 years, all linked
together by the observation of the title.
The rest of "Storm Front," however, is more

or less typical Billy Joel territory. "The
Downeaster Alexa," about a down-and-out fisherman, begins promisingly but degenerates into truly
stupid lyrics by its final verse. And "Leningrad,"
a song written about a friend Joel met during his
tour of the Soviet Union, is too pretentious for
its own good. In short, if you like Billy Joel
albums, you will probably like this one. If not,
forget it. And if you do enjoy such guilty
pleasures, and want to save face among your
friends, keep it to yourself. Maybe we can start
an encounter group.
—Christopher Bonanos
Melissa Etheridge—"Let Me Go" (Island
single)
On her latest single, Melissa Etheridge combines dusky, thick vocals with top-rate instrumental work. "Let Me Go" is rather minimalist in
production, a quality that brings out the excellent
solo work of bass player Kevin McCormick. The
lyrics themselves intertwine dense metaphors and
images to evoke the tension of a lover who
desperately wants to be released. Etheridge's vocal
tone, with its smoothly smoky quality, appropriately intensifies this atmosphere. Overall,
Etheridge has produced a single reminiscent of the
outmoded Joan Jett/Pat Benatar school of
songwriting, but of far superior quality.
—Christopher Bonanos
Heretix—A.D. (Island)
A strong vocal sound backed by competent
musicianship gives "A.D." an energetic hardrock feel. Heretix's six-song EP includes four
originals of consistently solid quality. "Always
Darkest," by guitarist Brian Hill, takes cues from
R.E.M.'s "Document" while constructing its
own, unique sound. The promising "World Full
of Tears" combines Edge-like guitar jangles with
clever and forceful vocals by lead singer Ray
Lemieux. The rhythm section—bassist Eric Hill
and drummer Marvin Huffman—also exhibit
styles influenced but not overwhelmed by their U2
counterparts. Also included on the EP are covers
of Donov,:n's "Season of the Witch"—it takes
courage to cover Donovan in 1989—and T. Rex's
"Mad Donna," both well executed. Despite their
undeniably silly name, Heretix gives a solid
postmodern rock sound to material that easily
could have been a horror.

Why are hard-boiled egg yolks
sometimes green?
When eggs are cooked, the proteins in the white break down
and release sulfur and hydrogen, which unite to form hydrogen
sulfide. This poisonous gas is what makes rotten eggs smell
like rotten eggs. The gas heads for the coolest part of the egg.
If you don't run the eggs under cold water as soon as they're ,
done, the coldest part is the yolk. The yolk contains iron (very
nutritious!) which combines with hydrogen sulfide to form a
green compound.
Prick the end of the egg before boiling—there's an air bubble
built-in to the egg which acts as a shock absorber for the growing embryo. The hole you smart cooks make lets the air out
slowly when it heats up and expands, instead of it cracking the
eggshell to relieve pressure.

Non-discriminatory discrimination
Recently, it was brought to the attention of the NewsLetter that applications for job opportunities at Hopkins
contain the following statement: "The Johns Hopkins
University is an equal opportunity employer and does not
discriminate on the basis of race, color, sex, religion, age,
homosexuality, national or ethnic origin..."
We received a private communication from an applicant,
who pointed out that "...clearly naming homosexuals as
a group against which the university does not discriminate
is, in itself discriminatory. It seems that this label would
be more "at home" in a statement like, 'The University
does not discriminate against Blacks, Women, Jews,

Homosexuals, or Mexicans.' Such a statement is on the
surface non-discriminatory, but is clearly offensive,
discriminatory, and oppressive."
This may at first glance seem a relatively minor point,
but it is an important distinction. The term that applications and all University documents should use is "sexual
orientation," rather than specifying homosexuality. It is
vital that the misleading term contained within the University's statement of non-discrimination be corrected immediately, especially if the University is sincere in its expressed desire to attract a diverse staff, faculty, and student body.

The will is not the deed (but it may be a committee)
As the semester draws to a close, it's time for one and
all to take a moment to reflect upon exactly what Student
Council accomplished during the past four months. Council
finally decided upon dates for Spring Fair after lengthy
debates and attempts to relocate the MCATS. Discussions
with security helped result in the installation of lights in
the Lower Quad.
A survey conducted by the Communication Committee,
which attempted to assess student concerns about the Book
Center, showed that over 80 percent of those polled supported the idea of a book swap. There is no question that
an alternative to the buy-back policy held by Barnes and
Noble has been needed for some time, and the proposed
Student Council Books-swap is an excellent solution. To
quote Margaret Thatcher, however, the will is not the deed.
One rather exciting potential change, as the result of
Council efforts, could be some improvements in the Book
Center services at Homewood. As with anything connected
with Barnes and Noble and Seiler's, the most rational thing
to do is adopt a we'll-believe-it-when-we-see-it attitude.
Yet when the buying rush begins next semester students
will enjoy increased security measures such as functional
lockers (a truly revolutionary concept) and bag-checkers.
So it seems the Student Council Representatives to the
Book Center Committee have managed to initiate sane
.improvements in the way Barnes and Noble serves the
University. The News-Letter hopes that Council and its
many committees will continue their work towards

cultivating a positive atmosphere here at the happy
Homewood homefront.

Time for a new station
For the first time in several years, a credible proposal
for the return of a student run radio station has been put
forward. The transformation, in 1985, of the previously
student-run WJHU into a professional radio station was
a regretable decision on the administration's part in the
first place. Although the decision to take WJHU out of
student hands was apparently influenced by administrative
concern about a perceived lack of adequate student cornmittment to the station, this should not be held against current efforts at radio revival.
University support for the proposed radio station would
be an acknowledgement of extensive undergraduate efforts
to overcome a reputation for apathy, and a very positive
indicator that undergraduate needs and interests have
become a genuine administrative concern.
This year's attempt to revive student radio at Hopkins
appears to be particularly well-conceived and sincerely intended. Whichever of the multiple suggestions for broadcast mediums are chosen, whether on FM or through the
University's electrical system, we strongly recommend
concrete steps towards the speedy renewal of student-run
radio at Hopkins.

Speaker's Corner
Craig Freeman
Chairman of the Black Student Union
In a lecture that was more
Cosby than canon, Henry L.
Gates disappointed during his lecture 'Race and the Canon.'
Gates is not your average lecturer. After all, this is the man
who criticizes the canon for returning values to the 'antebellum
esthetic position when men were
men and men were white, ... and
when women and people of color were voiceless, faceless servants and laborers, pouring tea
and filling brandy sniffers in the
boardrooms of old boys' clubs.'
As one of the editors of the Norton Anthology of Afro-American
Literature, Gates certainly came
well versed in the disenfranchisement of minorities in literature.
I expected Gates to come
prepared to battle the last bastion
of Eurocentric philosophy in
Baltimore. He must have been
briefed on the history departments' History of Africa, where
the only reference to blacks came
during a half hour lecture on
slavery. The truly sad part is the
History of Africa is one of only
four non-Western courses offered
on the undergraduate level by the
history department.
As a student and now professor
of African-American studies,
Gates could also have criticized
the school for not having one

faculty member knowledgeable
about black literature or history.
As it stands now, any student at
Hopkins desiring any more than
a passing comment on blacks in
literature or history must go to
Morgan State University.
Instead of addressing the issues
of race, education, and/or the
canon, Gates reminisced for an
hour on his childhood in the
presegregation South. At an institution that seems open to
change, Mr. Gates' words could
have helped enumerate the concerns of many students at
Hopkins. Instead he chose not to
help alter the views he struggled
so hard to overcome.

In the past couple of weeks I
have noticed a change brewing at
Hopkins. I think it started with a
successful Cultural Festival,
where people got to sample international cuisine and observe the
cultural kaleidoscope that
Hopkins has to offer.
The seed planted by Cultural
Fest grew quickly: the showing
of Spike Lee's movie "Do The
Right Thing" attracted far more
than anyone expected. It was
even more astonishing to see so
many stay for the discussion
afterwards.

"Do The Right Thing" need
only be the beginning. There is
a plethora of culturally diverse
events in the upcoming months to
expand everyone's horizons, but
they all depend on Universitywide support.
Take, for example, Black
History Month. The Black Student's Union is working with
several other groups to make this
February unforgettable. Umoja
Sasa, an African storytelling
group will open the month. The
African Heritage Dinner gives the
community a chance to taste
native African culinary treats, and
features an African dance troupe
for entertainment. The Grammy
award-winning gospel group
Take 6 will also perform in late
February.
These events were not scheduled only for black students. Ninety
percent of the black students have
tasted African cuisine, seen
African dancers, or even sung
gospel. The events were planned
to improve cultural awareness on
a previously lacking campus.
Their success lies in your
support.
On such a small, close-knit
campus like Hopkins, there is no
need for students not to be aware
of other cultures, religions, or interests. Take advantage of what
groups are trying to offer; learning and education involve more
than just reading textbooks.
Anyone interested in issues concerning black students is welcome
to attend Black Student Union
meetings. The next meeting will
be January 28, 1990, in the BSU
room (basement of AMR II)

In my last column I managed
to offend at least one Texan.
After reading the letter in last
week's issue which responded to
my Tex.s.s bashing, my advisor
told me,"Steve, you may as well
get used to people saying these
things about you. Once you start
doing scientific research your colleagues say things like this about
you all the time." So now I'm a
little better prepared for life.
This week I don't think I will
offend anyone other than possibly
my roommate. He comes from a
cattle-ranching family, so he
owes a lot to the existence of
cows. But I hate cows. There is
absolutely nothing good about
them. They exist so people can
have steak and hamburgers, and
so people like James Garner can
earn money advertising beef on
TV. We don't need beef to survive. They are a luxury form of
agriculture. If we were to put all
the resources that go into cattle
farming into other uses, it would
be surprising what gains could be
made toward ending world
hunger, saving the water supplies
of the arid regions of the U.S.,
reducing degradation of public
land, saving the rain forests in
Brazil. and even reducing the
threat of global warming. Unfortuoltely,
, I don't have the
nui,)')ers on hand to back up all
thesc itatements, but I know they
exist. 'just don't have the time
to look 'hem up right now. I can
say that it takes an incredible

amount of grain and water to keep
a cow running. If all the grain used in cattle feed lots was used for
feeding people instead, we could
make a significant dent in reducing the number of starving people in the world. Raising cows is
a very inefficient use of grain
supplies when one considers the
per pound nutrition received from
the beef. It is a serious waste of
water as well. One estimate is that
it takes 2500 gallons of water to
produce a one-pound steak. Since
much cattle farming occurs in
areas with continuously dropping
water tables, this is a rather
sobering fact to consider. Then
there are the rain forests. Why
does much of the forest clearing
occur? So people can graze cows
on the land. Where does much of
the beef go? The U.S. Let's look
at the global warming issue.
Some say that in order to save
the planet, humanity must first
have a true appreciation of this
place. We must change our
lifestyles a bit so that we are no
longer decoupled from our environment; stop spending every
day inside cars, buildings and
cities. We need to "get back to
nature" by taking walks through
the woods, watching wild
animals, looking at the clouds,
learning to appreciate our natural
surroundings. But trying to appreciate nature by looking at
cows in a field or buying a painting with happy cows is a
misguided step in this direction.
I've noticed that cows have
recently become an increasingly

common pop culture item . . .
you see them on mugs, T-shirts,
TV commercials, etc. This is
disturNing, for we would all be
better off if played a much reduced role in our lives.
When one looks at list of sources
of greenhouse gases (CO2
methane, CFC's, etc.) one of the
sources is "agriculture." One
usually thinks of agriculture as
growing crops. But plants absorb
CO2, so how can this be? The
major contribution from
agriculture is methane. And the
methane comes from bovine
flatulents, also known as cow
farts. Cows produce a
phenomenal amount of methane
during normal digestion.
The one remaining factor that
needs to be addressed is that of
saving the public land. Unknown
to me until last year was the fact
that much national forest land is
leased out to cattle ranchers so
their cattle can graze freely.
There are guidelines in place that
regulate how much grazing can
occur in a given area. and I like
to think they are adhered to. But
considering how the Forest Service is managing some of the
forests in the Pacific Northwest
and Alaska these days, I have to
wonder. Regardless of how well
the grazing guidelines are
obeyed, the mere presence of
cows in national forests is a
negative. For wild animals, the
cows represent competition for
food and a source of pollution for
their water supplies. For people,
I have my own stories.

Soundgarden—Louder Than Love (A&M)
While most of the free world seems to be
celebrating or analyzing the end of the 1980s, the
Hopkins Barnstormers seem hopelessly mired in
a trilogy that hurls us backward into the 1970s.
First was David Mamet's "Sexual Perversity in
Chicago," then Neil Simon's "California Suite."
Now comes Ralph Pape's "Say Goodnight,
Gracie."
Pape's work is a meandering rant on the meaning of life; besides the dated language, "Say
Goodnight, Gracie" is as refreshing or stale as
it ever was. The themes are cliched and universal, but the play works because it uses specificity
and anecdote to its advantage.
The setting is Greenwich Village: the living
room of struggling roommates Jerry (Robert Bell)
and Ginny (Pamela Becker). Jerry has just received his umpteenth rejection for an acting job, and
even the slightest transgression is enough to set
him off.
He isn't huffing and puffing alone for long,
however. Old friend Steve (Josh Mcllvain) arrives, gorilla mask draped over his head, for a protracted argument with Jerry over turkey noodle
soup. "What are you doing," Jerry asks, "rehearsing a monologue?" Exasperated by Steve's correct assessment of his histrionics, Jerry accuses
Steve of having a bad case of drug-induced
"silliness."
Soon Ginny arrives home; an airhead on a mission from God. She spends her opening moments
on stage cleaning up the apartment, offering empty
generalities to Jerry and Steve like an impatient
kindergarten teacher. She's not listening—she's
straightening. Becker really chews up the role, all
hands and hair, especially later in the play when
she puts on her bell-bottom jeans. The vintage
costume seems to invigorate her.

their high school reunion that night, along with

There's much to be said for Seattle's Soundgarden, first that many people have been waiting
for years to see what would happen when this
potential Next Big Thing got a shot at major-label
glory. "Louder Than Love," the band's entry into
the big leagues, offers plenty of interesting
possibilities. Soundgarden's celebration/parody of
raw phallic power and bare-chested maleness is
without doubt more engaging (and direct) than the
rituals of teenage petting and drunkenness supervised by the competition.
Although that alone is refreshing, it proves no
less contrived or silly after the initial fascination
wears off. Soundgarden undresses the rock cliche,
lies it down, revels in it, and leaves it apparently
despoiled and discredited. In fact, though, the band
usually just leaves it lying, which accounts for
much of the record's appeal.
Musically, "Louder Than Love" is a rocket
ride, a nail-biting trip that alternates graceful,
smooth coasting with a turbulent, disturbing grinding. But Soundgarden, appropriately, is more
likely to make hips swing than to elicit raised-fist
salutes. The band's sound pays off most handsomely when it shocks or surprises—although your
cup is sure to overflow once or twice in the course
of this 50-minute romp, several of the cuts bust
out too late or from too little.
The bottom line (for those who need one):
"Louder Than Love" is far more provocative than
most of the boom-boom floating around and glutting the pipes these days. It doesn't smother all
of its lumps in makeup; instead, it paves right over
them. At the same time, "Louder Than Love"
is totally ridiculous and pretentious, and I wish
Soundgarden would put its collective tongue back
in its own cheek.
—Terry Swords

The members of Soundgarden—from left, Kim Thayil, Matt Cameron, Jason Everman, and Chris Cornell

As it applies to rock and roll music, the term
"harmless" is something of an insult. As it applies to Poi Dog Pondering, though, it simply
describes their attitude—no insult at all. Their
debut for Columbia, collected from two previously
released EPs on the diminutive Texas Hotel label,
is like aespoonful of brown sugar, sweet as confection but without the processing.
Leader/songwriter Frank Orall and the additional six Poi Dogs play mostly acoustic instruments, and quite a lot of them: flugelhorns,
cellos, Latvian lap harps, accordions, banjos,
violins, and a battery of wood blocks and percussion all go into forming the Poi Dog sound.
Orall writes simple melodies and sets them to
simple beats (despite the percussive rattle), but
avoids sounding ordinary. This has something to
do with his funny-oblique lyrical slant which,

while producing occasionally awkward turns of
phrase ("She says my work/is like eating oat
meal/cold, cold, oat meal, again and again/and
she's right"), regards its own pretensions with

then smile.

group, but their ensemble playing is sufficiently
accomplished to carry the songs. Producer Mike,
Stewart does a terrific job recording Poi Dog, capturing all the easy swing without sacrificing the
rich textures of their instrumentation. Audio fidelity aside, this is a recording that half of New York
City's "top" producer-engineers could take a
lesson from.

"Poi Dog Pondering" isn't "important" in the
way Tracy Chapman or U2 is supposed to
they won't garner cover stories in Rolling Stone
or Life—but don't let that stop you from listening. Call it a guilty pleasure; or better yet, simply call it a pleasure.

Why are hard-boiled egg yolks
sometimes green?
When eggs are cooked, the proteins in the white break down
and release sulfur and hydrogen, which unite to form hydrogen
sulfide. This poisonous gas is what makes rotten eggs smell
like rotten eggs. The gas heads for the coolest part of the egg.
If you don't run the eggs under cold water as soon as they're ,
done, the coldest part is the yolk. The yolk contains iron (very
nutritious!) which combines with hydrogen sulfide to form a
green compound.
Prick the end of the egg before boiling—there's an air bubble
built-in to the egg which acts as a shock absorber for the growing embryo. The hole you smart cooks make lets the air out
slowly when it heats up and expands, instead of it cracking the
eggshell to relieve pressure.

Anyone familiar with the
Homewood Campus of the Johns
Hopkins University is accustomed to seeing construction sites.

6,000 square foot facility will be
completed by the spring of 1991.

began nearly five years ago. The
Lacrosse Foundation expects to
reach its fund raising goal of $1
million within the next few
months.

Director of the Lacrosse Foundation, cited two reasons for the
move. The new building will pro-

vide more room f6r exhibits and
offices, and will also allow space
for a 116-seat auditorium.

a misconception that we're a
Hopkins group or that we represent Baltimore exclusively." The

Center has housed the Hall of
Fame since 1964. This close
association has facilitated the
beliefs that the Foundation is tied
to Hopkins. "The new building
represents a new identity for els,"
said Stenersen.

independent, non-profit organization. Since its beginning in 1959
it has been dedicated to the promotion, development, and preservation of lacrosse.
When the Hall of Fame moves
to its new building, the Athletic
Center will reclaim the use of the
room. The area vacated by the
Hall of Fame will be used for
staff offices and staff meetings.

lounge for recruits, team receptions, and as a showcase for
trophies.
